","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"And yet, we balance our spending so that our dollars disproportionately go to incarceration, surveillance, and other carceral approaches that often undermine safety goals. This prioritization must change; we must begin investing in violence interruption, unarmed crisis response, safe passage to school programs, mentorship, streetlights, and the many other non-carceral, non-punitive programs that actually keep families and communities safe.","marks":[],"data":{}}]},{"nodeType":"paragraph","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Instead of a system in which police are the default response to all emergencies, we must build a system in which non-carceral, health-centered first responders offer assistance without further endangering community members or the person who is experiencing crisis. Moreover, we must invest in the non-carceral, community-based services and supports that prevent harm in the first place: well-paying employment, mental and physical health care, and affordable housing, to name a few. Only then can we reduce the overall incidence of harm and embrace genuine safety for all people.","marks":[],"data":{}}]}]}
